title: Acute Heart Failure

definition.criteria: - Rapid onset or worsening of heart failure symptoms
notes: - Can be new (de novo) or acute decompensation of chronic heart failure
- Pulmonary congestion ± systemic hypoperfusion

symptoms: - Severe shortness of breath (especially at rest)
investigations: - Bloods: Troponin, BNP/NT-proBNP, U&E, FBC, LFTs
diagnosis: - Clinical history + examination
- Elevated BNP/NT-proBNP
- Imaging (CXR, Echocardiography)
management_emergency: - Oxygen only if SpO2 < 94%
- Diuretics: Furosemide 40-80 mg IV bolus (may require higher doses)
- Nitrates: GTN spray (400-800 mcg sublingually) or IV infusion
- Non-invasive ventilation (CPAP or BiPAP) if severe hypoxia
- Treat underlying cause (arrhythmia, MI, infection)
- Consider inotropes (e.g., Dobutamine) if cardiogenic shock
prognosis_disposition: Admit to monitored bed or ICU if severe

title: Aortic Dissection

definition.criteria: - A tear in the aortic intima leading to separation of the layers of the aortic wall
notes: - Can rapidly lead to aortic rupture or organ ischemia

symptoms: - Sudden onset severe chest pain ("tearing" or "ripping" pain)
- Pain may radiate to the back
- Neurological symptoms if arteries are involved
investigations: - ECG: May show ischemia or be normal
- CT Angiography: Diagnostic test of choice
diagnosis: - Based on imaging (CT Angiography preferred)
- High clinical suspicion based on symptoms + signs

details: IV beta-blocker (e.g., Labetalol 20 mg IV over 2 min)

management_emergency: Pain control with opioids (e.g., morphine)
Emergency cardiothoracic surgery consult (especially for Type A dissection)
prognosis_disposition: - High mortality if not treated urgently
- Best outcomes with rapid diagnosis, blood pressure control, and surgery

title: Atrial Fibrillation (AF)

definition.criteria: - Irregular, often rapid heart rhythm originating from the atria
notes: - Loss of coordinated atrial contraction

signs: - Signs of heart failure (e.g., pulmonary oedema)
investigations: - ECG: No distinct P waves, irregular RR intervals
- Bloods: Thyroid function tests, U&E, FBC, cardiac enzymes if chest pain
- Echocardiography: Assess for structural heart disease
diagnosis: - Clinical history and examination
- Confirm diagnosis with ECG
management_emergency: If haemodynamically unstable: immediate DC cardioversion

details: Rate control: Beta-blockers (e.g., Metoprolol 2.5-5 mg IV), or calcium channel blockers
Consider chemical cardioversion (e.g., amiodarone 300 mg IV)

red_flags: - Risk of stroke if not anticoagulated
prognosis_disposition: - Good with rate/rhythm control and anticoagulation
- Risk of recurrence
- Long-term anticoagulation to reduce stroke risk

title: Deep Vein Thrombosis (DVT)

definition.criteria: - Formation of a thrombus (blood clot) in a deep vein, commonly in the legs
notes: - Can lead to pulmonary embolism if clot dislodges

symptoms: - Pain or tenderness in the calf or thigh
signs: - Calf circumference difference >3 cm compared to the other leg
- Positive Homan's sign (pain on dorsiflexion, not reliable)
investigations: - Compression venous Doppler ultrasound (first-line diagnostic test)
- Wells score to assess pre-test probability
diagnosis: - Based on clinical probability (Wells score) and confirmatory Doppler ultrasound

management_emergency.step: - Anticoagulation (start immediately if high suspicion even before confirmation):
details: - Low Molecular Weight Heparin (LMWH): Enoxaparin 1 mg/kg SC BD
- Or Direct Oral Anticoagulants (DOACs) like rivaroxaban/apixaban

management_emergency: - Elevate affected limb
- Analgesia for pain
red_flags: - Phlegmasia cerulea dolens (massive DVT leading to limb ischemia)
prognosis_disposition: - Generally good with anticoagulation
- Risk of post-thrombotic syndrome
- Requires long-term anticoagulation based on risk factors

title: Ruptured Abdominal Aortic Aneurysm (AAA)

definition.criteria: Life-threatening rupture of an abdominal aortic aneurysm
notes: Leads to massive intra-abdominal or retroperitoneal bleeding

symptoms: Sudden onset severe abdominal, back, or flank pain
signs: Tender, pulsatile abdominal mass (may be absent if large retroperitoneal bleed)
investigations: Bedside abdominal ultrasound: Rapid detection of AAA
CT angiography: Confirm diagnosis if patient is stable enough
Bloods: Crossmatch, FBC, U&E, coagulation profile
diagnosis: High clinical suspicion with hypotension, abdominal/back pain, and pulsatile mass
Confirm with bedside imaging
management_emergency: Immediate transfer to surgery (vascular surgery team)
Large bore IV access (2x 14-16G cannulas)
Fluid resuscitation (permissive hypotension: target systolic BP ~90 mmHg)
Crossmatch blood urgently
Analgesia (e.g., morphine)
Avoid delaying surgery for investigations
prognosis_disposition: Very high mortality if not operated immediately
Better outcomes if diagnosed pre-hospital and taken straight to theatre

title: Supraventricular Tachycardia (SVT)

definition.criteria: Rapid heart rhythm originating above the ventricles (atrium or AV node)
notes: Narrow complex tachycardia (>100 bpm)

signs: Signs of heart failure if severe
investigations: Bloods: Electrolytes, cardiac enzymes if chest pain
Consider echocardiography if structural heart disease suspected
diagnosis: Clinical presentation + ECG confirmation
Narrow QRS complex tachycardia without obvious P waves
management_emergency: If haemodynamically unstable: immediate synchronized DC cardioversion

details: Adenosine 6 mg IV bolus rapidly, repeat 12 mg IV if needed
Beta-blockers or calcium channel blockers if adenosine fails

red_flags: Chest pain or signs of myocardial infarction
prognosis_disposition: Excellent with acute treatment
May need long-term strategies (e.g., catheter ablation) if recurrent

title: Hypoglycemia

definition.criteria: Blood glucose level below 4.0 mmol/L
notes: Can result from excess insulin, missed meals, or increased physical activity

symptoms: Drowsiness or seizures in severe cases
investigations: Capillary blood glucose measurement (bedside finger-prick test)
Look for underlying causes: insulin overdose, sepsis, adrenal insufficiency
diagnosis: Blood glucose <4.0 mmol/L
Relief of symptoms after glucose administration confirms diagnosis (Whipple's triad)
management_emergency: If conscious and able to swallow: give 15-20g of fast-acting carbohydrate orally (e.g., glucose tablets, sugary drink)

management_emergency.step: If unconscious or unable to swallow:
details: IM glucagon 1 mg if IV access unavailable

management_emergency: Recheck glucose in 10-15 minutes and repeat treatment if needed
Identify and treat underlying cause
red_flags: Prolonged hypoglycemia leading to permanent brain injury
prognosis_disposition: Excellent with prompt recognition and treatment
Risk of recurrence if underlying cause not corrected

title: Diabetic Ketoacidosis (DKA)

definition.criteria: Life-threatening complication of diabetes mellitus (typically type 1)
notes: Characterized by hyperglycemia, metabolic acidosis, and ketonaemia

signs: Dehydration signs: dry mucous membranes, hypotension, tachycardia
Reduced level of consciousness in severe cases
investigations: Blood ketones: elevated (>3.0 mmol/L) or positive urinary ketones
Arterial or venous blood gas: metabolic acidosis (pH <7.3, bicarbonate <15 mmol/L)
diagnosis: Based on the triad: hyperglycemia, acidosis, and ketonaemia
management_emergency: IV fluid resuscitation (0.9% saline initially)
Fixed-rate insulin infusion (0.1 unit/kg/hour)
Potassium replacement as needed (based on serum levels)
Monitor blood glucose, ketones, and electrolytes closely (hourly)
Identify and treat underlying cause (infection, missed insulin, etc.)
prognosis_disposition: Good with early and appropriate treatment
Risk of mortality if delayed or complicated by cerebral edema, arrhythmias, or sepsis

title: Acute Appendicitis

definition.criteria: Inflammation of the appendix, usually caused by obstruction (e.g., fecalith)
notes: Most common surgical emergency in young adults

symptoms: Periumbilical pain migrating to right lower quadrant (RLQ)
signs: Rovsing's sign (RLQ pain on palpation of the left lower quadrant)
investigations: Ultrasound abdomen (first-line in children and pregnancy)
diagnosis: Clinical diagnosis supported by imaging (CT or ultrasound)
Alvarado score can aid clinical suspicion
management_emergency: Nil by mouth
IV fluids
IV antibiotics (e.g., piperacillin-tazobactam or amoxicillin-clavulanate)
Urgent surgical consultation for appendectomy (laparoscopic preferred)
Analgesia for pain control
prognosis_disposition: Excellent prognosis with early surgical intervention
Increased morbidity and hospital stay if perforation occurs

title: Acute Cholecystitis

definition.criteria: Acute inflammation of the gallbladder, usually due to obstruction of the cystic duct by gallstones.

investigations: LFTs: Mildly raised ALP and bilirubin
Ultrasound abdomen: Gallbladder wall thickening, stones, pericholecystic fluid
management_emergency: NPO (nil by mouth)
IV fluids
IV antibiotics (e.g., cefuroxime + metronidazole)
Analgesia (e.g., paracetamol or morphine)
Surgical referral for cholecystectomy (early or delayed)

title: Bowel Obstruction

definition.criteria: Mechanical or functional obstruction of the intestines, preventing normal movement of contents
notes: Can be small bowel or large bowel obstruction

symptoms: Absolute constipation (no passage of stool or gas)
signs: High-pitched bowel sounds (early) or absent bowel sounds (late/peritonitis)
Tenderness or peritonism (if strangulation or perforation)
investigations: Abdominal X-ray: dilated loops of bowel with air-fluid levels
CT abdomen and pelvis: confirms obstruction, identifies cause (tumor, hernia, adhesions)
Bloods: FBC, U&E, lactate (elevated lactate suggests ischemia)
diagnosis: Clinical suspicion plus radiological confirmation (CT or X-ray)
management_emergency: Nil by mouth
IV fluids for resuscitation
Nasogastric tube for decompression
Broad-spectrum IV antibiotics if strangulation suspected

details: Emergency surgery if strangulated, ischemic, or perforated bowel
Conservative management (drip and suck) if stable partial obstruction

red_flags: Signs of bowel strangulation (fever, tachycardia, peritonitis)
prognosis_disposition: Good if treated early
Risk of bowel ischemia, perforation, and death if delayed treatment

title: Cholangitis

definition.criteria: Infection and inflammation of the biliary tree, usually secondary to biliary obstruction (e.g. gallstones)
notes: Medical emergency due to risk of sepsis and multi-organ failure

investigations: Bloods: Elevated WBC, CRP, abnormal LFTs (especially raised bilirubin and ALP)
Abdominal ultrasound: dilated bile ducts, gallstones
MRCP (Magnetic Resonance Cholangiopancreatography) if diagnosis uncertain
diagnosis: Clinical diagnosis based on Charcot's triad: Fever + Jaundice + RUQ pain
Confirm with imaging (ultrasound or MRCP)
management_emergency: IV fluids for resuscitation
Broad-spectrum IV antibiotics (e.g., piperacillin-tazobactam)
Urgent biliary drainage (usually ERCP - Endoscopic Retrograde Cholangiopancreatography)
Analgesia for pain
red_flags: Signs of septic shock (lactic acidosis, organ dysfunction)
prognosis_disposition: Good with early intervention (antibiotics + drainage)
High mortality if delayed treatment
Risk of recurrent cholangitis if underlying cause not treated

title: Pancreatitis

definition.criteria: Inflammation of the pancreas, commonly caused by gallstones or alcohol
notes: Can range from mild to life-threatening severe pancreatitis

symptoms: Severe epigastric pain (often radiates to the back)
signs: Grey-Turner's sign (flank bruising) in severe hemorrhagic pancreatitis
investigations: Serum amylase or lipase (elevated; lipase more specific)
Full blood count, U&E, LFTs, CRP
CT abdomen (to assess severity and complications)
diagnosis: Clinical presentation plus elevated pancreatic enzymes (lipase or amylase >3x normal)
Imaging supportive if needed
management_emergency: Supportive care: IV fluids, oxygen
Nil by mouth initially (to rest pancreas)
Analgesia (e.g., IV opioids)
Treat underlying cause (e.g., ERCP for gallstone pancreatitis)
Antibiotics only if infection suspected (e.g., pancreatic necrosis)
prognosis_disposition: Mild cases recover well with supportive care
Severe cases have significant mortality (20-30% if necrotising)
Risk of chronic pancreatitis with repeated episodes

title: Perforated Peptic Ulcer

definition.criteria: Full-thickness ulceration of the stomach or duodenal wall leading to leakage of gastrointestinal contents into the peritoneal cavity
notes: Medical and surgical emergency

symptoms: Pain may radiate to the shoulder (due to diaphragmatic irritation)
History of dyspepsia or peptic ulcer disease
investigations: Erect chest X-ray (look for free air under the diaphragm)
Abdominal X-ray if chest X-ray inconclusive
Bloods: FBC, U&E, LFTs, CRP, amylase (to rule out pancreatitis)
diagnosis: Clinical suspicion plus imaging evidence of pneumoperitoneum (free air)
management_emergency: Nil by mouth
IV fluid resuscitation
Broad-spectrum IV antibiotics (e.g., piperacillin-tazobactam)
IV proton pump inhibitor (e.g., omeprazole)
Urgent surgical consultation for laparotomy or laparoscopic repair
red_flags: Delay in surgery >24 hours increases mortality
prognosis_disposition: Good prognosis with prompt surgery and antibiotics
High risk of complications if treatment delayed

title: Upper Gastrointestinal Bleed (Upper GI Bleed)

definition.criteria: Bleeding proximal to the ligament of Treitz (esophagus, stomach, duodenum)
notes: Common causes: peptic ulcers, esophageal varices, gastritis

signs: Stigmata of chronic liver disease (in variceal bleeding)
investigations: ECG if older or cardiac risk factors
diagnosis: Clinical suspicion plus confirmation by upper GI endoscopy
management_emergency: Resuscitation first: IV fluids (crystalloids), oxygen
Blood transfusion if needed (Hb <70 g/L or symptomatic)
IV proton pump inhibitor (e.g., omeprazole 80 mg bolus then infusion)
If variceal bleed suspected: IV octreotide + antibiotics (e.g., ceftriaxone)
Urgent endoscopy within 24 hours (sooner if hemodynamically unstable)
Endoscopic therapy: clipping, banding, sclerotherapy as appropriate
prognosis_disposition: Good prognosis with early intervention
High risk of rebleeding without proper treatment
Higher mortality in variceal bleeds and elderly patients

title: Abortion (Spontaneous/Missed)

definition.criteria: Spontaneous Abortion: Natural loss of pregnancy before 20 weeks
notes: Missed Abortion: Fetal death without expulsion of products of conception

signs: Speculum exam: closed cervix (in missed abortion), possible bleeding
No fetal heart activity on ultrasound (in missed abortion)
Soft, non-tender uterus unless complicated by infection
investigations: Transvaginal ultrasound (absent fetal heartbeat, empty gestational sac)
diagnosis: Based on ultrasound findings + clinical history
Absence of fetal cardiac activity after confirmed intrauterine pregnancy
management_emergency: Expectant management (allow spontaneous expulsion)
Medical management (misoprostol)
Surgical management (ERPC - evacuation of retained products of conception)
Anti-D immunoglobulin if Rh-negative
red_flags: Signs of infection (fever, foul vaginal discharge)
prognosis_disposition: Good prognosis physically after management
Important to offer psychological support and follow-up

title: Eclampsia

definition.criteria: Life-threatening complication of pre-eclampsia
notes: Characterized by new-onset seizures in a woman with pre-eclampsia

signs: Signs of multiorgan dysfunction (pulmonary edema, liver dysfunction, low platelets)
investigations: Clinical diagnosis (based on history and examination)
Bloods: FBC, U&E, LFTs, clotting profile
CT head if atypical features (to rule out other causes of seizures)
diagnosis: New-onset seizure in a woman with signs of pre-eclampsia after 20 weeks gestation or postpartum
management_emergency: Emergency ABCDE assessment
Oxygen therapy
Seizure management with IV magnesium sulfate (loading dose 4g IV over 5-10 min, then infusion 1g/hour)
Antihypertensive therapy (e.g., labetalol)
Urgent delivery of the fetus after maternal stabilization (usually by cesarean section)
prognosis_disposition: Good maternal and fetal outcomes with prompt recognition and management
Significant mortality and morbidity if untreated

title: Ectopic Pregnancy

definition.criteria: Implantation of a fertilized ovum outside the uterine cavity, most commonly in the fallopian tube
notes: Can rupture, causing life-threatening hemorrhage

symptoms: Vaginal bleeding (often lighter than menstrual bleeding)
signs: Adnexal mass or tenderness on pelvic examination
Signs of shock if rupture (hypotension, tachycardia)
investigations: Transvaginal ultrasound (absence of intrauterine pregnancy + adnexal mass)
diagnosis: Positive pregnancy test + absence of intrauterine pregnancy on ultrasound
High clinical suspicion in symptomatic patients

management_emergency.step: If unstable or signs of rupture:

details: Methotrexate IM (medical management if criteria met)

management_emergency: Rh(D) immunoglobulin for Rh-negative women
Close follow-up with serial beta-hCG if managed medically
red_flags: Signs of intraperitoneal bleeding (shoulder tip pain)
prognosis_disposition: Excellent prognosis with early diagnosis and treatment
Risk of future ectopic pregnancy increased

title: Miscarriage (Threatened, Inevitable, Complete, Incomplete)

definition.criteria: Spontaneous loss of pregnancy before 24 weeks of gestation
notes: Types include threatened, inevitable, incomplete, and complete miscarriage

symptoms: Loss of pregnancy symptoms (nausea, breast tenderness)
signs: Speculum exam: bleeding from cervical os, possible visible tissue
Bimanual exam: open or closed cervical os
investigations: Transvaginal ultrasound (assess fetal viability and retained products)
Full blood count (to assess blood loss)
diagnosis: Based on clinical presentation + ultrasound findings

detail: Threatened: bleeding but closed cervix, viable fetus
Inevitable: bleeding + open cervix, no expulsion yet
Complete: all products expelled, uterus empty

management_emergency: Threatened miscarriage: observation, reassurance, rest

details: Surgical management (evacuation of retained products of conception - ERPC)

management_emergency: Anti-D immunoglobulin for Rh-negative women
Analgesia for pain
red_flags: Signs of sepsis (fever, offensive vaginal discharge)
prognosis_disposition: Varies with type
Threatened miscarriage may continue to full-term pregnancy
Generally good prognosis after complete evacuation

title: Ovarian Cyst Rupture

definition.criteria: Rupture of an ovarian cyst causing leakage of cyst contents into the peritoneal cavity
notes: Can cause pain and internal bleeding

symptoms: Sudden onset unilateral lower abdominal pain
Pain may be sharp or stabbing
signs: Abdominal tenderness, often localized to one side
Signs of peritoneal irritation if significant hemorrhage
Hypotension and tachycardia if massive bleeding
investigations: Urine pregnancy test (to rule out ectopic pregnancy)
Transvaginal ultrasound (may show cyst, free fluid in pelvis)
Full blood count (to assess for anemia)
diagnosis: Based on clinical history, examination, and ultrasound findings
Exclusion of ectopic pregnancy essential

management_emergency.step: If hemodynamically stable and minimal bleeding:
If hemodynamically unstable or ongoing significant bleeding:

prognosis_disposition: Good prognosis with conservative management if bleeding minimal
Surgical outcomes excellent if needed

title: Pre-eclampsia

definition.criteria: Hypertension (>140/90 mmHg) and proteinuria (>300 mg/24h) developing after 20 weeks of gestation
notes: Can lead to serious maternal and fetal complications

symptoms: Epigastric or right upper quadrant pain
Swelling of face, hands, or feet (edema)
signs: Signs of organ dysfunction (e.g., pulmonary edema, low platelets)
investigations: Blood tests: FBC, U&E, LFTs, clotting profile
diagnosis: New hypertension and proteinuria after 20 weeks gestation
Or hypertension plus organ dysfunction (e.g., elevated liver enzymes, low platelets)
management_emergency: Admission to hospital for monitoring
Antihypertensives(e.g Labetalol first-line; alternatives include nifedipine, methyldopa)
Magnesium sulfate IV for seizure prophylaxis if severe
Corticosteroids if early delivery anticipated (<34 weeks gestation)
Delivery is the definitive treatment (timing depends on severity and gestational age)
red_flags: Signs of impending eclampsia (seizures, visual disturbances, headache)
HELLP syndrome (Hemolysis, Elevated Liver enzymes, Low Platelets)
prognosis_disposition: Good if recognized early and managed properly
Risk of recurrence in future pregnancies
Maternal and fetal morbidity and mortality if not treated

title: Severe Anaemia

definition.criteria: A significant reduction in hemoglobin concentration, typically defined as Hb <70 g/L in adults (or <80 g/L in patients with cardiovascular disease), requiring urgent evaluation and management.

symptoms: Shortness of breath on exertion or at rest
Chest pain or angina (in severe cases)
investigations: Full blood count (low Hb, MCV, reticulocyte count)
Stool occult blood (if GI bleed suspected)
Chest X-ray or ECG if cardiorespiratory symptoms
management_emergency: Oxygen therapy if hypoxic
IV fluids if hypotensive
Blood transfusion (typically if Hb < 70 g/L or symptomatic)
Treat underlying cause (e.g., GI bleeding, haemolysis, bone marrow failure)
Iron/B12/folate supplementation if deficient
Monitor vitals and Hb response post-transfusion
red_flags: New or worsening heart failure symptoms

title: Meningitis/Encephalitis

definition.criteria: Meningitis: Inflammation of the meninges, usually due to infection (bacterial or viral)
notes: Encephalitis: Inflammation of the brain parenchyma, often viral in origin

signs: Positive Kernig's sign (pain on extending the knee when the hip is flexed)
Positive Brudzinski's sign (involuntary hip/knee flexion when neck flexed)
Focal neurological signs (more common in encephalitis)
investigations: Lumbar puncture (LP) for cerebrospinal fluid (CSF) analysis (unless contraindicated)
CT brain before LP if raised intracranial pressure suspected
CSF: Gram stain, culture, glucose, protein, viral PCR
diagnosis: Clinical suspicion plus CSF analysis
Encephalitis confirmed with brain MRI and CSF viral PCR
management_emergency: Empiric IV antibiotics immediately (e.g., ceftriaxone 2 g IV BD)
Add IV acyclovir if encephalitis suspected
Dexamethasone IV if bacterial meningitis suspected
Supportive care: fluids, oxygen, seizure control if needed
Isolation if meningococcal disease suspected
red_flags: Signs of raised intracranial pressure (e.g., bradycardia, hypertension, irregular breathing)
prognosis_disposition: Mortality depends on prompt treatment
Risk of long-term neurological deficits, particularly in encephalitis
Vaccination can prevent some types (e.g., meningococcal, pneumococcal vaccines)

title: Sepsis

definition.criteria: Life-threatening organ dysfunction caused by a dysregulated host response to infection
notes: Identified clinically by the presence of infection plus signs of organ dysfunction

investigations: Full blood count, U&E, LFTs, CRP, lactate
Blood gases (to check for acidosis, lactate)
Urinalysis, chest X-ray, wound swabs if relevant
Source imaging (CT abdomen, etc.) if needed
diagnosis: Clinical suspicion of infection plus evidence of organ dysfunction (e.g., high lactate, hypotension)
qSOFA score (quick SOFA): RR >=22, altered mentation, SBP <=100 mmHg
management_emergency: Immediate administration of broad-spectrum IV antibiotics (within 1 hour)
IV fluid resuscitation: 30 mL/kg crystalloids for hypotension or lactate >=4 mmol/L
Oxygen supplementation if hypoxic
Source control (e.g., drain abscess, remove infected lines)
Vasopressors (e.g., norepinephrine) if hypotension persists after fluids
red_flags: Signs of multiple organ failure (renal, respiratory, cardiac)
prognosis_disposition: Mortality depends on severity and timeliness of intervention
Early recognition and treatment significantly improve outcomes

title: Head Injury

definition.criteria: Any trauma to the scalp, skull, or brain. Can range from minor concussion to life-threatening traumatic brain injury (TBI).

symptoms: Unequal pupils or focal neurological deficit
investigations: C-spine X-ray or CT if neck injury suspected
Monitor vitals and neurological status regularly
management_emergency: ABC assessment and cervical spine immobilisation
High-flow oxygen
Control bleeding
IV fluids if hypotensive
Neurosurgical referral if CT abnormal or signs of raised ICP
Admit if GCS <15, seizures, or other concerns
red_flags: Suspected skull fracture or CSF leak
More than one episode of vomiting
ct_head_indications: Suspected open or depressed skull fracture
Any sign of basal skull fracture (e.g., Battle's sign, raccoon eyes, CSF leak)
>1 episode of vomiting after head injury
Dangerous mechanism (e.g., fall >1m or 5 stairs, high-speed RTC)
Age >65 with head injury and any fall

title: Status Epilepticus

definition.criteria: A medical emergency where a seizure lasts more than 5 minutes or when seizures occur back-to-back without full recovery in between.

investigations: Neuroimaging (CT/MRI) if first episode or trauma suspected
management_emergency: Immediate ABC assessment
High-flow oxygen
IV access and blood tests
First-line :IV lorazepam 4 mg (repeat after 10 minutes if no response)
Second-line :IV phenytoin or levetiracetam loading
Third-line :Anaesthesia with midazolam/propofol and ICU admission
Treat underlying cause
red_flags: Unresponsive to first and second-line treatment
Suspected non-convulsive status in altered patients

title: Stroke (Ischemic and Hemorrhagic)

criteria: Ischemic Stroke: Blockage of a cerebral artery leading to brain ischemia and infarction
Hemorrhagic Stroke: Bleeding into brain tissue due to vessel rupture

symptoms: Sudden onset focal neurological deficits (weakness, numbness)
signs: Altered level of consciousness (more common in hemorrhagic)
Raised intracranial pressure signs: vomiting, bradycardia, hypertension (Cushing's reflex)
investigations: Non-contrast CT head (first-line to differentiate ischemic vs hemorrhagic)
Bloods: FBC, clotting profile, glucose, U&E
Carotid Doppler ultrasound if carotid disease suspected
diagnosis: Clinical assessment and confirmed by imaging (non-contrast CT initially)

details: Thrombolysis with alteplase within 4.5 hours if eligible
Mechanical thrombectomy for large vessel occlusion
Antiplatelet (Aspirin 300 mg PO after hemorrhage excluded)

management_emergency: Supportive Care: Oxygen ,Glucose control,Hydration
prognosis_disposition: Variable depending on size and location of stroke
Better outcomes with early intervention
Risk of long-term disability or death

title: Subarachnoid Hemorrhage (SAH)

definition.criteria: Bleeding into the subarachnoid space, most commonly due to rupture of a cerebral aneurysm.
notes: It is a neurological emergency.

investigations: Lumbar puncture (if CT is negative and suspicion remains) for xanthochromia
management_emergency: Immediate neurology/neurosurgery referral
Blood pressure control (target SBP < 160 mmHg)
Nimodipine 60 mg PO q4h to prevent vasospasm
Monitor and treat hydrocephalus or raised ICP
Analgesia and antiemetics
Surgical/endovascular intervention for aneurysm repair
red_flags: Sudden onset severe headache with loss of consciousness
Signs of raised ICP (papilledema, vomiting, altered mental status)

title: Transient Ischemic Attack (TIA)

definition.criteria: Brief, reversible episode of neurological dysfunction caused by ischemia
notes: No permanent infarction (symptoms resolve within 24 hours, usually within minutes)

symptoms: Sudden onset unilateral weakness or numbness
signs: May be normal by the time of examination
investigations: Carotid Doppler ultrasound (to check for stenosis)
diagnosis: Clinical diagnosis based on history
Confirm no evidence of stroke or bleed on imaging

details: Aspirin 300 mg PO immediately, then 75 mg daily

management_emergency: Manage underlying risk factors (hypertension, diabetes, AF)
High-risk patients (ABCD2 score >=4) need urgent specialist assessment (within 24h)
Carotid endarterectomy if significant stenosis (>70%)
prognosis_disposition: High risk of stroke within the next 48 hours
Good prognosis with early treatment and risk factor modification

title: Acute Angle-Closure Glaucoma

definition.criteria: A sudden rise in intraocular pressure (IOP) due to closure of the anterior chamber angle, obstructing aqueous humour outflow.
notes: It is a vision-threatening ophthalmic emergency.

symptoms: Blurred vision and halos around lights
Red eye with a mid-dilated, non-reactive pupil
management_emergency: Immediate ophthalmology consultation
IV acetazolamide 500 mg stat
Topical beta-blocker (e.g., timolol)
Topical pilocarpine (only once IOP begins to reduce)
IV mannitol in refractory cases
Definitive treatment: laser peripheral iridotomy (performed by specialist)
red_flags: Visual loss and eye pain unrelieved by analgesia
Unilateral red eye with mid-dilated pupil
Known history of glaucoma or risk factors (e.g., hyperopia, family history)

title: Central Retinal Artery Occlusion (CRAO)

definition.criteria: A sudden, painless, monocular loss of vision due to occlusion of the central retinal artery, often by an embolus or thrombus.

symptoms: Sudden, painless loss of vision in one eye
Visual acuity reduced to counting fingers or worse
Pale retina with 'cherry-red spot' at the macula on fundoscopy
investigations: Blood glucose, cholesterol, FBC, clotting screen
management_emergency: Ocular massage to dislodge embolus
Acetazolamide IV or oral to reduce IOP
Anterior chamber paracentesis (in specialist care)
Urgent referral to ophthalmology within 4-6 hours
Long-term: manage vascular risk factors, anticoagulation if AF present
red_flags: Visual loss lasting longer than 6 hours (prognosis worsens significantly)
Symptoms of temporal arteritis (e.g., jaw claudication, scalp tenderness)

title: Giant Cell Arteritis (GCA)

definition.criteria: A granulomatous vasculitis affecting large and medium-sized arteries, commonly the temporal arteries, seen in adults over 50.
notes: It is an ophthalmic emergency when associated with visual symptoms.

symptoms: Scalp tenderness (e.g., pain when combing hair)
Visual disturbance (e.g., transient or permanent vision loss)
Systemic symptoms: fever, weight loss, fatigue
investigations: Full blood count: normocytic anemia, thrombocytosis
Temporal artery biopsy (within 1-2 weeks of treatment)
Consider MRI or PET-CT in atypical cases
management_emergency: Immediate high-dose corticosteroids (e.g., prednisolone 40-60 mg daily)
If visual symptoms: IV methylprednisolone 500-1000 mg for 3 days
Do not delay treatment for biopsy
Bone protection (calcium, vitamin D, bisphosphonates)
PPI for GI protection
red_flags: Symptoms suggestive of stroke or amaurosis fugax
Constitutional symptoms with elevated inflammatory markers

title: Orbital Cellulitis

definition.criteria: A serious infection of the soft tissues of the orbit posterior to the orbital septum, often secondary to sinusitis, that can lead to vision loss or intracranial complications.

investigations: Urgent contrast-enhanced CT orbit and sinuses
Consider swabs from conjunctiva or sinus drainage
Lumbar puncture if signs of meningitis
management_emergency: Admit to hospital
IV broad-spectrum antibiotics (e.g., ceftriaxone + metronidazole or co-amoxiclav)
Surgical drainage if abscess is present or worsening
Monitor vision and signs of intracranial spread
Treat underlying sinusitis if present
red_flags: Cavernous sinus thrombosis signs (e.g., bilateral involvement, cranial nerve palsies)

title: Retinal Detachment

definition.criteria: A separation of the neurosensory retina from the underlying retinal pigment epithelium, leading to vision loss.
notes: It is an ophthalmic emergency.

symptoms: Sudden onset of floaters or flashes of light
Painless loss of vision ('curtain' or shadow across field of vision)
Decreased visual acuity (if macula is involved)
investigations: Urgent dilated fundoscopy (may show detached retina as a grey, mobile membrane)
Do not perform tonometry if globe rupture suspected
management_emergency: Immediate ophthalmology referral
Positioning: lie with the detached area dependent
Avoid exertion
Surgical repair: pneumatic retinopexy, scleral buckle, or vitrectomy depending on type/location
red_flags: Family or personal history of retinal detachment
High myopia, recent ocular surgery, or trauma

title: Scleritis

definition.criteria: A painful, destructive inflammatory condition affecting the sclera, often associated with systemic autoimmune diseases.

symptoms: Severe, boring eye pain (often worse at night and with eye movement)
Tenderness to palpation of the globe
investigations: Autoimmune workup: ANA, RF, ANCA, ESR/CRP
Syphilis and TB screening if indicated
B-scan ultrasound if posterior scleritis suspected
management_emergency: Urgent ophthalmology referral
Oral NSAIDs or systemic corticosteroids
Immunosuppressive agents (e.g., methotrexate, azathioprine) if autoimmune
Treat underlying systemic disease
Avoid topical steroids unless directed by ophthalmology
red_flags: Proptosis or restriction of eye movements (posterior scleritis)
Suspected necrotising scleritis (can lead to globe perforation)
Associated with rheumatoid arthritis or granulomatosis with polyangiitis

title: Uveitis

definition.criteria: Inflammation of the uveal tract (iris, ciliary body, choroid), classified as anterior, intermediate, posterior, or panuveitis depending on the site.

symptoms: Eye pain and redness (especially around the limbus)
investigations: Slit-lamp examination (cells and flare in anterior chamber)
Intraocular pressure (may be low or high)
Consider blood tests: HLA-B27, ANA, ACE, syphilis serology, TB testing
management_emergency: Urgent ophthalmology referral
Topical corticosteroids (e.g., prednisolone acetate)
Cycloplegics (e.g., atropine) to prevent synechiae
Treat underlying systemic cause (e.g., infection, autoimmune disease)
Systemic immunosuppressants if recurrent or severe
red_flags: Associated systemic symptoms (e.g., joint pain, skin lesions)

title: Asthma Exacerbation

definition.criteria: Acute or subacute worsening of asthma symptoms requiring a change in treatment
notes: Caused by airway inflammation, bronchoconstriction, and mucus production

symptoms: Cough (often worse at night or early morning)
Difficulty speaking full sentences (in severe cases)
signs: Silent chest in life-threatening asthma (ominous sign)
investigations: ABG if severe: hypoxia, hypercapnia, acidosis
Chest X-ray if suspicion of pneumothorax or infection
diagnosis: Clinical diagnosis based on history and examination
Supported by low PEF and hypoxia
management_emergency: High flow oxygen to maintain SpO2 94-98%
Inhaled short-acting beta-agonists (Salbutamol) via nebuliser or MDI with spacer
Inhaled ipratropium bromide if severe
Oral or IV corticosteroids (e.g., Prednisolone 40-50 mg PO or Hydrocortisone 100 mg IV)
Magnesium sulfate IV (2 g over 20 min) if life-threatening
Consider non-invasive ventilation or intubation if worsening respiratory failure
red_flags: Rising PaCO2 on ABG (suggests failing ventilation)
prognosis_disposition: Good prognosis with prompt treatment
Risk of recurrence if underlying asthma poorly controlled
Requires follow-up and preventive inhaler optimisation

title: Pneumothorax (including Tension Pneumothorax)

definition.criteria: Pneumothorax: Presence of air in the pleural space causing lung collapse
notes: Tension pneumothorax: Life-threatening accumulation of air under pressure, causing mediastinal shift and hemodynamic compromise

symptoms: If tension pneumothorax: severe dyspnoea, hypotension, cyanosis
signs: Reduced or absent breath sounds on affected side
Tracheal deviation away from affected side (in tension pneumothorax)
investigations: Chest X-ray (first-line, except in tension pneumothorax where immediate treatment is priority)
Ultrasound (can quickly detect absence of lung sliding)
diagnosis: Clinical diagnosis in suspected tension pneumothorax (do not delay for imaging)
Confirm with imaging in stable cases

management_emergency.step: Immediate needle decompression if tension pneumothorax:
details: Insert large bore needle into 2nd intercostal space, midclavicular line

management_emergency: Then insert chest drain into 5th intercostal space, midaxillary line
prognosis_disposition: Good prognosis if treated early
Risk of recurrence, especially in primary spontaneous pneumothorax
May need surgical pleurodesis if recurrent

title: Pulmonary Embolism (PE)

criteria: Blockage of a pulmonary artery or its branches by a blood clot (usually from a DVT)
Can cause life-threatening cardiovascular and respiratory compromise

investigations: CT Pulmonary Angiography (CTPA) - gold standard diagnostic test
ECG: Sinus tachycardia, S1Q3T3 pattern (classic but uncommon)
diagnosis: High clinical suspicion + confirmed by CTPA or V/Q scan
management_emergency: Oxygen supplementation
Thrombolysis (e.g., alteplase) if massive PE with shock
Consider surgical or catheter-directed thrombectomy in selected cases
red_flags: Right heart strain on echo or ECG
prognosis_disposition: Good if treated promptly with anticoagulation
Higher mortality in massive PE
Risk of chronic thromboembolic pulmonary hypertension (CTEPH)

title: Acute Urinary Retention

definition.criteria: Sudden and painful inability to voluntarily pass urine, typically due to outflow obstruction or neurological dysfunction.

investigations: Bladder scan to confirm retention (typically >500 mL)
Consider pelvic/abdominal ultrasound if masses suspected
management_emergency: Immediate urethral catheterization
If unsuccessful or contraindicated, use suprapubic catheter
Monitor urine output and post-obstructive diuresis
Start alpha-blockers (e.g., tamsulosin)
Treat underlying cause (e.g., BPH, constipation, infection)
red_flags: Bilateral lower limb weakness or numbness
Loss of anal tone or saddle anesthesia (suggesting cauda equina)

title: Renal Colic

definition.criteria: Acute, severe flank or abdominal pain due to obstruction of the urinary tract, most commonly by kidney stones.

symptoms: Sudden onset unilateral flank pain radiating to groin
No peritonism (pain is colicky, not constant)
management_emergency: Analgesia: NSAIDs (e.g., diclofenac), opioids if needed
IV fluids if dehydrated
Antiemetics for nausea
Alpha-blockers (e.g., tamsulosin) to facilitate stone passage
Outpatient follow-up if stone <5 mm and stable
Urology referral if stone >6 mm, uncontrolled pain, or infection

title: Testicular Torsion

definition.criteria: Twisting of the spermatic cord leading to ischemia of the testis
notes: Urological emergency; testicular viability decreases rapidly with time

symptoms: Sudden onset severe unilateral scrotal pain
signs: Absent cremasteric reflex (no elevation of testicle with stroking of inner thigh)
investigations: Doppler ultrasound of scrotum (shows reduced or absent blood flow) if diagnosis unclear
Do not delay surgery for imaging if high clinical suspicion
diagnosis: Clinical diagnosis based on sudden onset pain, absent cremasteric reflex, and physical findings
management_emergency: Immediate surgical exploration and detorsion (orchiopexy)
Bilateral orchiopexy usually performed (even if torsion is unilateral)
If testis non-viable: orchiectomy (removal of testis)
red_flags: Delayed presentation (>6 hours) leads to decreased chance of salvage
Signs of sepsis if necrosis occurs
prognosis_disposition: Testicular salvage rates are excellent if surgery within 6 hours
Testicular loss is common if treatment delayed beyond 12 hours
